question.text: You hear about a new business coming to town and you don't approve of the new owners. What do you want to tell the politicians and neighbors?

options.option: This makes me uncomfortable, I vote for single family zoning as a way to keep newcomers out.
options.consequence: People are over crowding in single family homes creating squalid conditions.

options.option: Let's welcome them and make our neighborhood more interesting!
options.consequence: Apartments are built to accommodate spiking population of folks who can't afford single family homes.

options.option: I mind my own business and keep to myself.
options.consequence: People are over crowding in single family homes creating squalid conditions.

event: Sudden uptick in immigration from Europe
fact: In 1914, real estate developer Duncan McDuffie was one of the early proponents of single-family zoning in Berkeley, CA to prevent a dance hall owned by a Black resident from moving into houses he was trying to sell. He worried that families of color moving into the neighborhood would decrease the desirability of the neighborhood and decrease property values. By advocating for single-family zoning, McDuffie and other developers at the time were attempting to price out social groups whom they deemed to be less desirable for the neighborhood.[1] This makes single-family zoning one of many exclusionary zoning policies intended to limit who was able to afford living in a certain neighborhood. The goal of limiting certain neighborhoods to only single-family homes meant that only families who could afford to buy an entire house could live in the neighborhood. There was not the option to subdivide housing so that families who could not afford to buy the whole property could live in smaller units.

question.text: Single Family Zoning is being argued in the Supreme Court. Luckily you know a few of the Justices and they will listen to your opinion. What do you want to tell them?

options.option: The reasons people live in different types of housing is economic, this zoning segregates people and exclusionary zoning should be struck down.
options.consequence: The city has very few restrictions on apartments so the university is able to easily find developers to build a variety of new dorms throughout the area.  The university is able to attract some incredible talent and the town becomes known for scientific discoveries and cultural events!

options.option: It's important to protect the character of a neighborhood. If a majority of people in a region want to exclude certain housing types, they should be free to do so.
options.consequence: The city has few places where dorm housing is allowed, preventing the university from expanding as much as they want.  Students must be extremely privileged to attend the university.

options.option: There's more money to be made in a neighborhood if different housing types are available.  Exclusionary zoning isn't economically smart, strike it down and deem it unconstitutional.
options.consequence: The city has very few restrictions on apartments so the university is able to easily find developers to build a variety of new dorms throughout the area.  The university is able to attract some incredible talent and the town becomes known for scientific discoveries and cultural events!

options.option: This isn't happening in my town so I don't think it's right for me to have an opinion here.
options.consequence: The city has few places where dorm housing is allowed, preventing the university from expanding as much as they want.  Students must be extremely privileged to attend the university.

event: The town university is so popular that it wants to expand.
fact: In 1926, the Supreme Court upheld exclusionary zoning in a vote of 6-3 during the case Euclid v. Ambler. Exclusionary zoning today is also known as Euclidean zoning for this reason.

question.text: Your coworker bought a plot of land in your neighborhood. They want to split it into two and build four tiny homes - one to live in and 3 to rent out. They are complaining to you that the city won't let them because there is a minimum lot size that a house can be in the region. He asked if you could influence city council to lower the size to allow for a tiny home. What do you want to do?

options.option: Tiny homes are neat, why not? Advocate to get minimum lot size significantly lowered.
options.consequence: The city relaxes regulations and you're able to split up your lot and order a pre-fab small house to put on the smaller lot.  Your mom frequently criticizes your landscaping choices but she is now the reason you can get enough sleep in one day, since she's right there to help with the baby.

options.option: Having renters living in tiny homes could change the character of the neighborhood. This doesn't seem like a good idea.
options.consequence: Your mom can't find a smaller place for herself so stays where she is, a 2-hour drive away. You spend $1,500 on childcare a month and have to cut back on your retirement savings.

options.option: They should have looked into this before buying the land. Sounds like their problem, not mine.
options.consequence: Your mom can't find a smaller place for herself so stays where she is, a 2-hour drive away. You spend $1,500 on childcare a month and have to cut back on your retirement savings.

options.option: If the minimum lot size is lowered, I could divide my lot in order to build a tiny home for my aging mother to live in. This would help me out too! You advocate for this change.
options.consequence: The city relaxes regulations and you're able to split up your lot and order a pre-fab small house to put on the smaller lot. Your mom frequently criticizes your landscaping choices but she is now the reason you can get enough sleep in one day, since she's right there to help with the baby.

event: Your mom decides to downsize, she is sick of taking care of a big house, and ready for a fresh start, plus she wants to be nearby to help out with your new baby.
fact: Minimum Lot Sizes used to be necessary to allow room for septic tanks and wells, but now are no longer needed. Austin, TX has an average lot size of 8,629 sq ft, and Philadelphia, PA has an average lot size of 1,089 sq ft.

question.text: Your friend purchased a brand new 1955 Chevy Bel Air and wants to be sure they can park it for free anywhere in the city. They ask for your help bringing this plan to life. What do you tell city council?

options.option: You don't believe in the city subsidizing free parking. Let the market decide how much parking is built.
options.consequence: The main street is alive on First Fridays and you walk there from your house with your entire family. Street musicians perform on the sidewalks, interesting foods are sold from street vendors, and you watch artists paint the sunset at the park.

options.option: You think we can move more people with public transit and don't want to fund free parking.
options.consequence: The main street is alive on First Fridays and you walk there from your house with your entire family. Street musicians perform on the sidewalks, interesting foods are sold from street vendors, and you watch artists paint the sunset at the park.

options.option: You have a nice car too and love the idea. We need as much parking as possible to prevent crowded streets!
options.consequence: You park in a parking garage for the event, but after a few hours of looking at art, you can't remember where you parked... it takes you an hour of walking through all 11 floors in order to find your car.  You're exhausted when you get home.

event: The city decides to implement "First Fridays" where the first Friday of the month is dedicated to local art galleries and musicians, an event for the whole family
fact: Transportation planners point out that parking minimums increase the distance between destinations, making cities and towns less walkable, thereby perpetuating a cycle of less viable transit and mobility options, the need for more driving, and—subsequently—even more parking.

question.text: A developer wants to build 50 apartments on an empty lot with 50% of units dedicated to homeless veterans. They didn't do an extensive environment review though... What do you want your city council friends to do?

options.option: 50 apartments? That will be loud and cause more traffic. Get them to oppose it with any means necessary.
options.consequence: City regulations mean the most cost effective place to build is outside the city in rural areas. More natural environment outside the city is destroyed for new homes since that's the only land available.

options.option: Environmental reviews must ALWAYS be done. This developer should be sued.
options.consequence: City regulations mean the most cost effective place to build is outside the city in rural areas. More natural environment outside the city is destroyed for new homes since that's the only land available.

options.option: Supporting veterans is everything! Let's get them the housing they deserve, plus the empty lot isn't doing anything for anyone. It's a win/win for the neighborhood and the Vets!
options.consequence: Dense housing is created in the city for veterans. They enjoy living near each other and playing chess in the park, meeting at the local coffee shop, and running into old pals.

options.option: I'd rather stay out of this, they can do whatever they want since it's not on my property.
options.consequence: City regulations mean the most cost effective place to build is outside the city in rural areas.  More natural environment outside the city is destroyed for new homes since that's the only land available.

event: The Federal government distributes funds to build housing for homeless veterans
fact: Environmental studies are often used to prevent new housing from being built in cities, and often causes environment destruction outside of cities. In LA, a local nonprofit developer proposed several years ago to build a 49-unit apartment building on the lot—with 24 homes set aside for disabled veterans experiencing homelessness—it was slammed with an environmental lawsuit. A single angry neighbor was able to delay the project, thanks to a piece of legislation known as the California Environmental Quality Act. Although a 189-page assessment found that all possible environmental effects could be mitigated, the suit demanded that planners spend years conducting additional environmental research. The site—covered in cracked concrete and lined with a barbed-wire-topped chain-link fence—remains empty to this day.

question.text: Earthquake! The main highway by the waterfront has collapsed. What should the city do?

options.option: Highways are important infrastructure for a city, especially for people who live in the suburbs. Rebuild it at any cost.
options.consequence: You and your partner drive downtown to attend the ceremony, you get stuck in traffic and you become very stressed. You drive around looking for parking and end up missing the first 30 minutes of the event.

options.option: I don't live near the highway so I don't have an opinion, they can do anything they want.
options.consequence: You and your partner drive downtown to attend the ceremony, you get stuck in traffic and you become very stressed. You drive around looking for parking and end up missing the first 30 minutes of the event.

options.option: It's expensive to rebuild, and we should be investing in public transportation and bike lanes to clean up the environment not putting more cars on the road. Let's clean it up and convert it to a boulevard so we can build commercial and residential space in its place.
options.consequence: You and your partner take the train downtown and sit by the water for a while before the banquet, reflecting on your hard work that led you to this award. You can hear the birds and enjoy people watching on the pier together before going to the banquet.

event: You are awarded an honorable citizen award from the mayor and get invited to a fancy banquet at the waterfront downtown.
fact: In 1989, an earthquake deeply damaged the Embarcadero Freeway in San Francisco. The freeway was cleared and converted into a boulevard - housing in the area increased 51% and jobs increased 23%.

question.text: Your city is experiencing a tragic epidemic of children being killed by cars when playing in the street. What should the city do?

options.option: Create a media campaign targeted  at parents shaming them for allowing  their children to play in the street. It's dangerous!
options.consequence: You drive your child to school and someone cuts you off, putting you in a bad mood. When you arrive at the school, there's so many other parents in cars that you only have 30 seconds to wish your child good luck and wave goodbye. You notice another child walking up behind your car, coughing after breathing in exhaust fumes.

options.option: Children should be able to play in public streets without the risk of death. I'm starting a protest group and we're going to lie in the street and demand bicycle infrastructure instead.
options.consequence: You and your child bike together to the school, side by side. Your child tells you that they're most excited about science class and making friends. You drop them off and take a picture together at the school entrance and then bike to work.

options.option: Sadly this is something out of our control. Parents are solely responsible for their children, they need to be more responsible but there's nothing I feel like I can personally do to stop this.
options.consequence: You and your child bike together to the school, side by side. Your child tells you that they're most excited about science class and making friends. You drop them off and take a picture together at the school entrance and then bike to work.

event: It's your child's first day of school!
fact: In the 1970s in Amsterdam, 9 people were killed everyday in traffic. People started mass protests to stop roadway expansion and demand bicycling infrastructure. Their main slogan was "stop the child murder". The Dutch are known for their incredible bicycling infrastructure today, and people of all ages and abilities are mobile in their cities.

question.text: Your neighbor posts on Nextdoor about how they're concerned your neighborhood doesn't have much racial and socioeconomic diversity. They ask what the neighborhood could do to change this?

options.option: People should just make their own choices naturally about where to live. It will all work out.
options.consequence: You show up to the restaurant and the server asks if you don't mind wait a bit because the waitress for your table hasn't arrived yet. She shows up 20min late as she was stuck in traffic since she can't afford to live anywhere near where she works due to the high cost of housing-out of range for students or waitresses.

options.option: I'd love a more inclusive  neighborhood too. I post on Nextdoor that I'm  committed to changing this and am starting a group to work on diversifying the neighborhood.
options.consequence: You and your partner show up to the restaurant and are pleased to discover your neighbor Sarah is your waitress! Sarah is a student at UCB who babysits your kids sometimes and you're happy to catch up with her.

options.option: It's not right to categorize people by their race or income. Don't get involved here.
options.consequence: You show up to the restaurant and the server asks if you don't mind wait a bit because the waitress for your table hasn't arrived yet. She shows up 20min late as she was stuck in traffic since she can't afford to live anywhere near where she works due to the high cost of housing-out of range for students or waitresses.

event: You have dinner reservations for your anniversary this coming weekend at your favorite restaurant.
fact: The National Fair Share Act was proposed by John Boger in 1993. He proposed that non-integrated neighborhoods should lose mortgage interest and property tax deductions unless they have a proportion of African American and low- and moderate-income population in its region.

question.text: A developer wants to build 3bd/3bath rowhomes on a lot in your neighborhood, but the current laws require 5ft of space between houses. They ask you if you can advocate for changing this rule for them. What do you do?

options.option: I think row homes seem dangerous and noisy, especially in the case of fire. I have to tell him I just can't help get this project approved.
options.consequence: You park your car in the garage and walk into your home. You don't see anyone outside. You sit in your recliner and watch the news and drink a beer, feeling a bit lonely and sad.

options.option: The law is the law, he shouldn't have put so much effort into a plan that's illegal. This isn't worth my time.
options.consequence: You park your car in the garage and walk into your home. You don't see anyone outside. You sit in your recliner and watch the news and drink a beer, feeling a bit lonely and sad.

options.option: I've always loved the row homes in places like Brooklyn, London, and San Francisco (Painted Ladies!), and find them quite charming. I'll reach out to my friend in city council to see if there is a way to abolish setback laws.
options.consequence: You walk home from work and sit on your front step. Your neighbor is outside too and asks if you're okay. They bring you a glass of iced tea and you sit together, people watching and letting off steam. You're glad to have friendly neighbors to lend a hand  when times are hard.

options.option: Living in a row home (sharing a wall?) sounds awful to me, but I know some young folks who have wanted one and couldn't find one anywhere nearby. I think helping the developer advocate for the end of row home 'setback laws' is a good idea.
options.consequence: You walk home from work and sit on your front step. Your neighbor is outside too and asks if you're okay. They bring you a glass of iced tea and you sit together, people watching and letting off steam. You're glad to have friendly neighbors to lend a hand  when times are hard.

event: You have a rough day at work and are getting home at the end of the day.
fact: Modern construction codes require fireproofing shared walls. Rowhomes can add charm and community to a neighborhood and are a great option for families to live in a city center, however are illegal to build in most cities.
